Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks spilling over the sides, a silent accusation. As a wife, I know I should help fold it, share the load, keep our home running smoothly. My husband’s been working late all week, and I promised I’d take care of it. But my phone buzzes—a message from Alex, my boyfriend. He’s leaving for Europe tomorrow, gone for months, and this is our last weekend together. He wants to spend every moment with me, just us, making memories before the distance stretches between us. My heart aches with guilt and longing. I want to be the reliable wife, the one who keeps her promises, but I also want to be the loving girlfriend, present and attentive. The laundry sits untouched, and I feel pulled in two directions, each role demanding more than I can give. I pace the living room, torn, the weight of expectation pressing down, unsure which part of me to disappoint.
